history.text: Right, so, The Social Network.
What year did that film come out?
It got really good reviews. 9/10s all across the board from RT to Metacritic.
One sec.
It is nice to see Justin Timberlake in a more serious role
Yeah. It was a little surprising.
I don't think I've seen Eisenburg anywhere since, either.
I didn't realize that it was adapted from a book.
Oh, damn, me neither.
I never read Accidental Billionaires.
I haven't either.
It was hailed as an important film and an important book, which was fairly interesting.
I think it's good. I like it.
Very true.
The first big scene of it was fairly bombastic tbh
It is said that not everything is to be believed so I wonder how much is opinion vs facts
Zuckerberg emerging from a relationship to start being an asshole
Insane to think that guy might be a candidate in two years, but that's off topic.
I didn't realize he went to Harvard.
I feel like the most damning things are facts, but the rest is movie stuff
The fine details are definitely fabricated.
Amazing that all of this started when he was only 19
Yeah
He was using the house he was staying in in Palo Alto as headquarters, which was nuts.
Like, he was almost exactly like a child.
I'm floored that the name of multibillion industry was a one off comment by a fellow student
It's still such a terrible name too!
But that was really surprising.
Very high brow that it was only ivy league at first.
Sorta makes ivys look terrible imo
I don't think the facebook stuff was flattering
To anyone really, I think the moral was like, people will ruin you and everyone else to get freakishly rich
And there's nothing anyone can do about it but suffer
I think the original intention was social networking and it grew beyond that too quickly
It became a monster, and I think Zuckerburg did too.
Like the court stuff was nightmareish.
I didn't know there were that many lawsuits tied to it. I thought it was only one.
The scene with Zuckerberg facebook stalking his (former girlfriend?) Albright while they lower that dude into the ground was chilling
While the original idea was someone elses I don't think it would have gotten as far without zuckerberg's input
The whole final third of it was insane.
He might be wildly unpleasant but there is no denying he is quite bright
The character in the movie telling Zuckerberg to settle because everyone hates him and he's annoying as hell
And he's still one of the most powerful people on the planet then and he's still pounding sand about being so broken
Good conversation btw. Goodbye!
The jury would have never sided with him though so the out of court settlement was probably the smartest move ever on his part

uid1response.feedback: There was an insert in one of the paragraphs about an entirely different movie.
